item.title: Scores Reported Dead in Nice, France, as Truck Plows Into Bastille Day Crowd
item.description: Graphic images showed the truck tearing through the crowd. The driver was shot to death by the police, and France’s president called the assault “a monstrosity.”
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN, ADAM NOSSITER and CHRISTOPHER MELE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Nice, a Vibrant Celebration Gives Way to a Trail of Death
item.media:description: A woman received help after being injured Thursday night by a truck that plowed into a crowd in Nice, France, killing dozens.
item.description: A speeding truck that barreled into a crowd on Bastille Day left a trail of bodies, shock and despair.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Truck Attack in Nice, France: What We Know, and What We Don’t
item.description: President François Hollande said it was a terrorist attack, but authorities didn’t know who was responsible, or why.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Hong Kong Says Legislative Candidates Must Endorse Chinese Rule
item.media:description: The chief executive of Hong Kong, Leung Chun-ying, in June. Some scholars and lawmakers said the announcement could harm political freedoms guaranteed under law.
item.description: As calls for autonomy grow, Hong Kong’s government wants legislative candidates to pledge that the city remains an “inalienable part” of China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Leader of 2014 Massacre at Pakistani School Is Killed in U.S. Airstrike
item.description: Omar Mansoor was the leader of the Taliban faction Tariq Gidar and was known as one of Pakistan’s most brutal militants.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Salvadoran Court Overturns Wartime Amnesty, Paving Way for Prosecutions
item.description: The Supreme Court struck down a law that had protected members of the military, rebel groups and death squads for more than two decades.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and GENE PALUMBO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: John Kerry Meets Vladimir Putin to Discuss New Syria Plan
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Secretary of State John Kerry on Thursday during their meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow.
item.description: The proposed agreement would create a joint Russia-U.S. command center to share intelligence and targeting information for “integrated operations.”
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and ANNE BARNARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What China’s Economic Growth Figures Mean
item.media:description: Passengers on a bus in Beijing. China is assuring its people that its economy is going in the right direction.
item.description: China on Friday reported its second-quarter economic growth figures. The numbers are among the world’s most closely watched, but data from the country are notoriously questionable.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: 6,000 Headstones After ’95 Srebrenica Massacre, and Counting
item.description: Since Carlotta Gall last reported from Srebrenica in 2000, some of the 8,372 victims of a mass killing have been buried there, with more remains discovered each year.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Philip May, a Financier Who May Find It Harder to Be Low Key
item.media:description: Philip May listened to his wife’s first speech as prime minister from a circumspect distance.
item.description: The spouse of Britain’s new first gentleman is likely to face a brighter spotlight and harsher scrutiny for his ties to the world of finance.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: New Spies Went for a Joyride in Moscow. Russia Isn’t Happy.
item.description: A video of about 50 recent graduates of the Federal Security Service riding in a fleet of luxury S.U.V.s has provoked national contempt, and may get the graduates fired.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Trilobites: An Icelandic Volcano Reveals Secrets of Its Eruption
item.media:description: A plane flying over the Bardarbunga volcano spewing lava and smoke on Sep. 14, 2014.
item.description: The gradual collapse of the top of Bardarbunga volcano in 2014 contributed to a lengthy lava flow.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Family of Slain Man in India May Be Charged With Cow Slaughter
item.media:description: Relatives mourned Mohammad Ikhlaq, who was killed by a mob in Dadri, in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, in September.
item.media:credit: K. Asif/India Today Group, via Getty Images
item.description: A court ruled that villagers can open a criminal case against the family of a Muslim man bludgeoned to death over rumors that he slaughtered and ate a cow.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Microsoft Wins Appeal on Overseas Data Searches
item.description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed a ruling that Microsoft must turn over email stored in a data center in Dublin.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and CECILIA KANG

item.title: 7 Times Boris Johnson, Britain’s New Foreign Secretary, Was Anything but Diplomatic
item.media:description: Boris Johnson at the Fight for Peace Academy in London in 2014, when he was mayor.
item.description: An author, journalist and former mayor of London, Mr. Johnson has a rich history of gaffes and controversies.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Szigetvar Journal: Townspeople and Treasure Hunters in Hungary Search for a Sultan’s Buried Heart
item.media:description: Searching for the remains of the Ottoman sultan Suleiman the Magnificent near Szigetvar, Hungary.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: Residents of Szigetvar hope the discovery of a 16th-century encampment from the last days of Suleiman the Magnificent could spell a revival for their town.
item.dc:creator: HELENE BIENVENU

item.title: After Celebrating South China Sea Win, Reality Sets In for the Philippines
item.media:description: Patrons at a restaurant in Makati, the Philippines, reacted to news of an international tribunal’s ruling against Beijing’s claims in the South China Sea.
item.description: The Philippine government, not wanting to antagonize Beijing, has urged people to “exercise restraint and sobriety.”
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Theresa May’s British Cabinet Has New Faces but Old Divides
item.media:description: Michael Gove at Downing Street in London on Tuesday. He was fired as justice minister on Thursday by Prime Minister Theresa May as she continued to make a series of big changes.
item.media:credit: Chris J Ratcliffe/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The new prime minister continued to make big changes in her government, but could face splits over how to withdraw from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Bank of England Holds Key Interest Rate Steady Despite Uncertainty Over ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Mark J. Carney, the Bank of England’s governor, has sought to reassure investors after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.description: The British central bank signaled that it could lower the rate as soon as August in a bid to bolster the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Google Faces New Round of Antitrust Charges in Europe
item.description: The claims relate to some of the search giant’s online advertising tools and parts of its search business linked to online shopping.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and JAMES KANTER

item.title: The Interpreter: The South China Sea: Explaining the Dispute
item.media:description: An woman wearing a hat representing a Philippines Navy boat with other protesters during a demonstration in front of the Chinese Consulate in Manila on Tuesday.
item.description: Why this body of water is considered such a big deal, and why it may be a harbinger of global power politics in the decades ahead.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Sinosphere: A Portrait of the Millennial Generation Changing China
item.media:description: Young commuters crowding a subway car in Beijing. Alec Ash’s new book follows six Chinese millennials whose dreams and decisions provide signposts for their country’s direction.
item.description: Alec Ash, author of “Wish Lanterns: Young Lives in New China,” views this generation as the “thin end of a wedge” that is slowly opening Chinese society.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.category: While Were Here: China Stories from a Writers Colony (Book)

item.title: Russia Looks to Populate Its Far East. Wimps Need Not Apply.
item.media:description: Yuri A. Bugaev, a Cossack on a scouting trip from St. Petersburg, Russia, waded through grass and reeds on land near the town of Kamen-Rybolov in the Russian Far East.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A determined Cossack’s quest reveals the gap between fantasy and harsh reality in Moscow’s effort to settle a sparsely populated region.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.category: Ministry for the Development of the Far East (Russia)

item.title: What in the World: When the Planets Align, Delhi Drowns in a Chorus of ‘I Do’
item.media:description: Guests dancing at a wedding in New Delhi on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Vivek Singh for The New York Times
item.description: A certain astrological configuration is considered auspicious by many Indians, and in the capital it means something very specific: a wedding apocalypse.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: What in the World: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)
item.description: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: At Mexico’s Top Restaurants, Service Too Good to Be Good
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by LuckyImages, sisqopote/shutterstock
item.description: At many of the country’s higher-end establishments, waiters are arguably so attentive it borders on annoying.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Editorial: Keeping NATO Relevant and United
item.description: Amid Russia’s aggressive tactics and Britain’s Brexit vote, the alliance serves as a regional anchor and a reassurance to Eastern European nations.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Putin Loves Brexit
item.description: In the Russian president’s view, what makes Europe weaker makes him stronger.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW FOXALL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Why the U.S. Military Can’t Fix Syria
item.media:description: Smoke rises from a U.S.-led coalition airstrike in Kobane, Syria, in 2014.
item.description: More American involvement in the Middle East’s biggest quagmire will definitely end badly.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN SIMON and JONATHAN STEVENSON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
